title: Bilateral Mixed Hearing Loss with Hyperacusis and Tinnitus
chief_complaint: I've had hearing loss for 25 years that's getting worse, along with ringing and a 'motor noise' in my ears. Sudden loud sounds like a cup hitting a table or a soda opening are painful to me, so I often wear an earplug in my left ear instead of my hearing aid.

problem_summary.onset: Progressive over the last 25 years; hyperacusis worsened over the last 2 years.
problem_summary.course: Progressive decline; acute worsening of sensitivity after acoustic trauma (shotgun blast) 2 years ago.
problem_summary.laterality: Bilateral; Right ear is poorer than the Left.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Intermittent bilateral tinnitus (ringing), 'motor noise' and hum in left ear, intermittent otalgia/pressure, severe hyperacusis/recruitment, history of dizziness.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Patient avoids using hearing aids or turns them off due to loudness sensitivity; wears earplugs in the better ear.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Seeking help for hearing loss but struggles with tolerance of amplification.

history.present_illness: Patient reports bilateral progressive mixed hearing loss. Significant hyperacusis (pain to loud sounds) developed/worsened 2 years ago after a shotgun was fired near his ears without protection. He currently manages by wearing an earplug in the left ear and turning off the right hearing aid.
history.otologic_history: History of ear infections over past 7 years with multiple sets of PE tubes. Severe dizziness 10 years ago, now occasional. Diagnosed with left external otitis during intervention phase.
history.noise_exposure_history: Occupational exposure as a carpenter for over 30 years. Acoustic trauma from shotgun blast 2 years ago.
history.prior_management: Has worn binaural BTE hearing aids for about 15 years.
history.patient_goals: Improve hearing without pain from loud sounds.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Bilateral mixed hearing loss. Right ear: Moderately severe to severe sloping to profound, then recovering slightly at 8kHz. Left ear: Moderate to moderately severe sloping to profound. Significant air-bone gaps present bilaterally.

numeric_results.Bone_Conduction: Indicates mixed loss; BC thresholds generally 40-60 dB HL range.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRT scores agree with PTA. Word recognition is good in the right ear and fair/good in the left ear at suprathreshold levels.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Normal tympanograms (Type A) bilaterally despite the mixed hearing loss (suggestive of otosclerosis or ossicular stiffness not affecting compliance peak).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Ipsilateral and contralateral acoustic reflexes were absent from 500 to 4,000 Hz in both ears.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a bilateral, asymmetric mixed hearing loss, worse in the right ear, characterized by significant air-bone gaps but normal tympanograms and absent acoustic reflexes. This pattern, confirmed by CT, is consistent with cochlear otosclerosis superimposed on noise-induced hearing loss. The patient exhibits significant hyperacusis and recruitment, complicating amplification use.
counseling_points: Explain the 'mixed' nature of the hearing loss: a combination of damage to the nerve (from noise/aging) and the middle/inner ear bone hardening (otosclerosis).
Discuss Hyperacusis: Over-protecting your ears (using earplugs) can actually make the sensitivity worse over time. We need to slowly reintroduce sound.
Hearing Aid Strategy: We will use hearing aids with specific 'transient noise reduction' to soften sudden loud sounds (like dishes clanking) to make them comfortable.
Medical Referral: Review the otologist's findings regarding otosclerosis and the treatment for the current outer ear infection.
notes_for_actor: Portray a patient who is visibly anxious about loud noises. You might flinch if a door slams or a pen drops.
Emphasize that you have been wearing hearing aids for years but recently stopped because 'the world got too loud and painful.'
Mention the shotgun incident as the specific moment you feel the sensitivity got much worse.
